_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
0.1 INTRODUCTION
This Risk Management Plan is part of GE Silicones continuing commitment to minimize the potential impact from our facility on our workers, our community neighbors, or the environment.  It is the stated policy of GE Silicones to safely manage our site operations.  In addition, we have prepared contingency plans to be used in the unlikely event that a major accident should occur. 
We believe it is important for all interested parties to have access to information that can help them better understand our business and our facility.  If you have any questions about this document, or any other aspect of our company or our plans, please contact our Human Relations/Community Relations Representative at (518) 233-2304.
0.2 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Our company is committed to operating safe and environmentally sound manufacturing facilities wherever we do business.  Protection of our neighbors and workers is the highest priority.  This ongoing commitment to worker and public safety is demonstrated through the resources invested for safe design, operation and maintenance of our facilities.
In order to provide products of the highest quality for our customers, the GE Silicones Waterford NY facility uses and generates in it's manufacturing process some chemicals that are classified as toxic or flammable.  We are committed to comply with governing laws, regulations and engineering standards as well as systematic assessments to manage and maintain a safe operation.  Our operating practices and procedures ensure that numerous controls are implemented to prevent an accidental release of a chemical.  However, if a major release does occur, our trained on-site emergency organization will be activated.  This organization includes a fire brigade as well as medical and hazardous material response teams.
Our intensive series of internal reviews and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) external

audit process have validated the strengths of the programs we have in place.   We have been recognized by OSHA, under the voluntary Protection Program (VPP), as being among the best in the nation for worker safety.  We have been designated a MERIT site.
0.3 DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The GE Silicones plant is on an 800-acre tract along the Hudson River in the Town of Waterford, New York, about 2 miles north of the Village of Waterford.  It was built in 1947 and currently employs about 1470 people in New York State's Capital region.  GE Silicones manufactures silicones, a unique material based on a chain of alternating silicon and oxygen atoms.  The products include synthetic fluids, emulsions, resins, rubbers, sealants and specialty chemicals.  Our products are used in the automotive, construction, electronic, computer, appliance and consumer goods industries to name a few.
The site also serves as the Global Headquarters for GE's Silicone Business.
In order to insure quality products, quality service and quality of life, GE has invested more than $700 million in the site for expansion, capital improvement, safety and environmental protection since the site was developed in 1947.
The Waterford, N.Y. plant uses eight chemicals that are regulated under the EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) rule.  Four of these are from the family of chemicals known as chlorosilanes.  These are methyltrichlorosilane, dimethyldichlorosilane, trimethylchlorosilane,(all regulated toxic substances), and trichlorosilane, (a regulated flammable substance).  We also use methyl chloride, (a regulated toxic substance); hydrogen chloride solutions (greater than 37% by weight), (a regulated toxic substance); and hydrogen, (a regulated flammable substance).  
Methyl chloride and hydrogen are raw materials that are used to manufacture chlorosilanes and other components of silicones.  Chlorosilanes are the building blocks for all of our silicone products.  Hydrogen chlorid

e is a by-product of our manufacturing process that is recycled internally.
0.4 HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS
As part of our risk management planning, we have specifically identified the type of event that, should it ever occur, would have the most negative impacts on our employees and our neighbors.  This is known as the Worst-Case Scenario (WCS).  As defined by EPA, we are required to assume that the numerous engineering and administrative safety controls we have in place to prevent or mitigate such accidents have all failed at once.  A simultaneous failure of all safety controls and mitigation measures would be a highly unlikely event. EPA defines a worst-case scenario as a catastrophic failure, which is an event that essentially results in the instantaneous release of the contents in the largest single vessel on-site that results in the greatest distance to the EPA-defined level-of-concern.  
The worst-case scenario at Waterford would involve the catastrophic failure of a distillation column containing chlorosilanes. The quantity of material released is assumed to be 460,000 pounds of EPA-regulated chlorosilanes.  Under this scenario, the chlorosilanes are assumed to evaporate and the vapors disperse in the direction of the prevailing wind.  Furthermore, the chlorosilanes are assumed to react with moisture in the air to form hydrogen chloride gas.  According to EPA guidelines, exposure to hydrogen chloride can occur without serious health effects up to levels of 20 parts per million (0.030 mg per liter) for approximately one hour. 
A scenario used to meet the Alternative Release Scenario (ARS) requirements of the regulation involves overfilling a railcar and subsequently sending 1,000 pounds of methyltrichlorosilane liquid into a tank containing water.  The water effectively cleans or "scrubs" this chemical from the air under normal conditions, but the system could become overloaded in this situation and convert the methyltrichlorosilane to hydrogen chloride gas. Mu

ch of the 740 pounds of hydrogen chloride gas could be released to the atmosphere out the top of the tank.  The response of our operators would be to shutdown and isolate the flow of material within five minutes. 
The Alternative Release Scenario for dimethyldichlorosilane involves the failure of a 2-inch pipe connected to a slurry wagon while a material containing dimethyldichlorosilane is being transferred into the wagon.  Up to 560 pounds of liquid dimethyldichlorosilane is released in one minute before the attendant operator closes valves and stops the transfer.  As the dimethyldichlorosilane vaporizes the vapors are assumed to react with moisture in the air to produce hydrogen chloride gas. The response to this scenario includes our emergency brigade, who would apply a water deluge spray to the release within 10 minutes.  
The Alternative Release Scenario for trimethylchlorosilane is similar to that of methyltrichlorosilane.  During a railroad tank car loading operation, the car is overfilled sending liquid material into a vent scrubber at a rate of 38 gallons per minute for five minutes.  The trimethylchlorosilane is contacted with water in the scrubber and converted to hydrogen chloride gas, thereby overloading the scrubber.  Total quantity of trimethylchlorosilane released is 1,350 pounds.  Operators attending the operation would shutdown and isolation of the tank car within five minutes.  
The Alternative Release Scenario for hydrogen chloride involves the over-pressurization of a vessel in a silicone manufacturing process.  Up to 4,500 pounds of hydrogen chloride gas is released through a pressure relief valve over a 60-minute period.  The response to this scenario includes our emergency brigade, who would apply a water deluge spray to the release within 10 minutes.  
Methyl chloride is the last of the regulated toxic materials for which EPA requires an Alternative Release Scenario.  The scenario involves an electrical power failure that results in a press

ure increase in a methyl chloride production vessel.  Up to 950 pounds of methyl chloride are released to the atmosphere over a one-minute period through a pressure relief valve.  
The Worst-Case Scenario (WCS) involving flammable materials at the facility involves the catastrophic failure of a trichlorosilane storage tank, resulting in the instantaneous release of up to 294,000 pounds of trichlorosilane gas.  The scenario assumes the gas will ignite and result in a vapor cloud explosion.  
We are required by EPA to report a second, similar Worst-Case Scenario (WCS) for hydrogen that affects a slightly different area off-site.  This scenario involves 10,690 pounds of hydrogen.
The Alternative Release Scenario (ARS) for all flammable materials involves the failure of a compressor in the trichlorosilane manufacturing process.  The scenario involves the release of trichlorosilane vapor at a rate of 5,000 pounds per hour.  Trained operators would diagnose the problem, then shutdown and isolate the process within five minutes, thereby limiting the total quantity of trichlorosilane released to 420 pounds.
0.5 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION / CHEMICAL- SPECIFIC      PREVENTION STEPS
GE Silicones has implemented a comprehensive program to prevent accidental releases of highly hazardous chemicals known as Process Safety Management (PSM).  We are also subject to the New York State Chemical Bulk Storage (CBS) regulation that focuses on preventing spills and releases from hazardous material storage tanks. PSM and CBS are an integral part of working safely at GE Silicones.  PSM ensures that proper safety information is in place; operating procedures are followed; chemical hazards are identified; employees and contractors are trained; and critical equipment is properly inspected and maintained.  PSM satisfies the accidental release prevention program requirements of the RMP.  
Some of the many, specific safety features to prevent a chemical accident include:
? Computerized

cause of the incident and to learn how to prevent future occurrences.
 EPA requires that all incidents involving regulated chemicals that resulted in any off-site impact or significant on-site impacts are reported in this document.  These reporting criteria will include an incident of an RMP-regulated chemical that involves any of the following types of impact:
? Off-site:  death, injury, property damage, environmental damage, evacuation, or shelter-in-place; or,
? On-site:  death, injury, or significant property damage.  
 During the previous five-year period, one incident occurred at the plant site involving an RMP-regulated chemical that met at least one of these reporting criteria.  
 On August 2, 1997 a release of 125 pounds of methyltrichlorosilane occurred as a result of overfilling a railroad tank car.  As the excess pressure was relieved from the tank car through a vent system, a section of pipe failed.  When the pipe failed, methyltrichlorosilane was released, and it reacted with water to form hydrogen chloride gas.  The plume of hydrogen chloride drifted across the plant boundary and across the highway that passes through the plant site.  There was no fire or environmental impacts and no one was injured from this incident.  GE reported the release to the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation and the National Response Center as a precautionary measure.  Waterford Police closed the highway. Nearby residents were notified by Waterford Police to stay inside (or "shelter in place") while the GE emergency brigade isolated the system and eliminated the hydrogen chloride gas.  Following this incident, the hazards of the system were reviewed and improvements were made to prevent future occurrences.
 0.7 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
 The Waterford, New York site maintains a written emergency response program designed to protect workers, the public, and the environment in the event of a major accidental release.  All of our employees are trained in t

he proper response to an incident.  We also invest in the equipment needed to respond to emergencies, both on-site and off-site.  Our trained fire brigade, medical and chemical response teams work closely with area hospitals, industries and other emergency response organizations in the Capital Region.  
 We have mutual aid agreements with the emergency response organizations in the Town of Waterford, the Town of Halfmoon and Saratoga, Rensselaer and Albany counties to insure that adequate resources are available to respond on-site and off-site to chemical emergencies.  As a result of the agreements, the GE Silicones emergency brigade has responded to many non-GE off-site chemical emergencies.
 Recent emergency training drills, organized and directed by the GE Silicones emergency brigade, have included:
? A simulated airplane crash into a hydrogen chloride distillation column and adjacent large oil storage tank with the fire and police departments of the Town of Waterford and the emergency management officials of Saratoga County.
? A table-top simulation of a leak from a large chemical storage tank with representatives of local emergency response organizations in the Town of Waterford.
 Ongoing training exercises are important to the GE emergency response organization and help prepare our partners in the community for emergency response in the unlikely event of a major industrial accident. 
 GE personnel have helped develop emergency preparedness plans for local communities.  In addition, they are members of local emergency planning and community emergency response groups.  We have provided training and equipment to our mutual aid partners. As consistent with the Saratoga County Emergency Plan, GE will work through the Waterford Police and Saratoga Emergency Management Office to communicate any appropriate actions to be taken by the public in the event of a chemical emergency.
 GE has developed a program to implement the "Wally Wise" shelter in place training program
